header.title: Ya kununga bisambulu (Oraciones Triunfadoras)
authors: Tata Nkisi Malongo 7 Rayos N... N... Tabula Ndigue
Sâr Tau Mar Camael R+ S.I.L.I

central_thesis: This compilation serves as a practical grimoire of secret, powerful prayers (bisambulu) from the Nzo Vititi Kongo and Nzo Sarabanda lineages of Palo Monte Mayombe, designed to enable practitioners to invoke, honor, protect, and manipulate divine, ancestral, elemental, and spiritual forces for diverse ritualistic and magical operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introducción
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the purpose of the book: to collect and preserve powerful, secret prayers from the Nzo Vititi Kongo and Nzo Sarabanda branches of Palo Monte Mayombe, which were previously held privately by the Tata Nsasi Zarabanda Nsusu Yampemba Mayimbe and Yaya Isasi Zarabanda Munangueta. It describes the format, with each prayer presented in Kikongo, followed by its Spanish translation and practical explanation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Mpungu Nzambi (Plegaria a Dios y los Antepasados)
structure_content.summary: A foundational prayer to invoke the supreme God (Nzambi) and the ancestors. It acknowledges God as the all-powerful creator, present in stars, sun, moon, life, death, fire, air, earth, water, and all living beings, seeking divine protection and guidance. The prayer is performed by placing the Patibemba (spiritual signature) on the ground between the practitioner and their Nganga.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Kwase (Rezo a Nzambi)
structure_content.summary: A daily prayer to Nzambi, addressed as the 'Center of the Universe' and 'source of light,' expressing love and dependence. It seeks blessings for one's actions, wisdom, and justice, placing all endeavors under Nzambi's benevolent influence. This prayer is to be recited daily upon waking.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu zitisa na Nzambi (Rezo de respeto a Nzambi)
structure_content.summary: This prayer is a declaration of respect and humility before Nzambi, acknowledging God as the sole creator, sustainer, and helper. The practitioner testifies to their own impotence and Nzambi's omnipotence, celebrating divine wealth and power. It is used to recognize Nzambi's hand in all successes and outcomes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Nganga Nkisi (Para invocar a la Prenda)
structure_content.summary: An invocation directed at the Nganga, or sacred Prenda, recognizing it as a 'Nature source of my power' and 'house of all spirits.' The prayer seeks the Nganga's wisdom, guidance, and protection, emphasizing the practitioner's role as a loyal follower and its vital element in the world. It involves placing the practitioner's Patibemba between themselves and the Nganga.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu na Ngolo Nganga (Para la fuerza de la prenda)
structure_content.summary: This prayer is a declaration of the Nganga's inherent power, identifying it with fundamental elements: water, word, messenger, dove, fire, life, death, and air. It asserts the Nganga's dominion over the earth and its ability to grow and manifest through the power of the four elements. Its purpose is to attract and infuse power and energy into the substances and foundations used in ceremonies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu Kukuyuela (Para tata y yaya Nganga)
structure_content.summary: A prayer affirming the practitioner's connection to elemental forces, identifying with 'the earth, the dog, the hunter,' and asserting the ability to open the invisible world. It seeks special sensory powers—hearing spirits, perceiving their presence through scent, guiding them with words, and feeling their contact—from the spiritual foundations, particularly in conjunction with Nkuyo (Lucero) and Mpaka.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Mintantu (Contra los enemigos)
structure_content.summary: A potent and aggressive prayer designed to neutralize enemies. It invokes powerful protective and destructive forces to blind, deafen, incapacitate, and ultimately destroy adversaries, emphasizing that no harm can reach the practitioner. It is specifically recommended for use when suspecting an enemy is actively performing negative magic against the practitioner, with a special emphasis on the word 'KO'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Mpungo Nzila (Sellar pactos con la Naturaleza)
structure_content.summary: This prayer focuses on sealing pacts with nature, invoking the spirits of the wind, the power of stones, the wisdom of ancestors, the force of vegetation, and the energy of animals (fish, birds, insects). The practitioner consecrates these elements for both benevolent and malevolent uses, depending on the will of the guiding spirit. It is essential when gathering ritual elements and establishing new treaties with 'palos' (woods/herbs).

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Kadia a Mpemba (Letanía al Espíritu del Mal)
structure_content.summary: An invocation directed at 'Diablo maléfico' (evil devil), understood within the Kongo context not as a Western demon but as a powerful spirit of the night, abysses, and the earthly underworld. It seeks to awaken and enlist this spirit for manipulating 'forces of evil.' This prayer is used to consecrate elements and ceremonies intended for working with these potent, often dark, spiritual energies.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Bakuluntu Bantete (Para invocar a los Antepasados)
structure_content.summary: A prayer to invoke the power of the ancestors (Bakuluntu Bantete) for strength, support, and liberation from malevolent spirits, illness, and misfortune. The practitioner identifies as a descendant continuing their work, seeking ancestral protection and the power associated with mongo (mountains), sea creatures, birds, and celestial bodies. This prayer integrates ancestors directly into rituals to enhance their efficacy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Zibudila Sambu (Empezar las ceremonias)
structure_content.summary: An opening invocation for ceremonies, designed to 'open the way' for the practitioner's voice, allowing it to penetrate spiritual mysteries. It calls upon celestial and elemental powers to feed the energy of the ritual, asserting the practitioner's role as a creator and the light that opens universal doors. This prayer unifies and activates the spiritual components of the prenda.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Kanga Sambu (Finalizar las ceremonias)
structure_content.summary: A closing prayer marking the end of a ceremony or a day of magical work. It acknowledges the setting sun and the night's mantle, expressing contentment with the completed work and the cyclical continuation of creation into new dimensions. This prayer provides ritual closure and signifies successful completion of operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Bima Biena Ku Zulu (Para obtener la fuerza de los astros)
structure_content.summary: This prayer is recited to draw cosmic energy from celestial bodies and phenomena: the sun's rays, the moon's influence, guiding stars, colors of the day, shadows of night, the silence of death, and the song of life. It seeks to empower the magical elements used in ceremonies and offerings, providing strength to Mayomberos for their work.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Sambula Maza Ma Ngiobila (consagración del Agua)
structure_content.summary: A prayer for consecrating ceremonial water, transforming it into a powerful medium to repel negative influences and attract positive ones. It recognizes water as the 'principle of my energy' and seeks to infuse it with the powers of the cosmos. This is vital for purificatory and fortifying baths, and for sacralizing natural water sources like rivers and lagoons, especially in rituals involving Ngui with Kalunga.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Sambula Ntumna (Purificar animales)
structure_content.summary: This prayer is used to purify animals prior to sacrifice or offering. It acknowledges the animal as a symbol and spiritual offering, emphasizing the importance of treating it with respect, speaking to it as one would to the Nganga itself, as it serves as a 'link that communicates the two worlds.' It stresses that only unblemished animals, purified with Mansa, Malafo, and Nzunga, should be used.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Sambula Zinganga ti Makutu (Nombrar a la prenda, Fundamento o Resguardo a entregar)
structure_content.summary: A crucial prayer for naming and consecrating a new Nganga, fundamento (foundation), or resguardo (protective charm). It invokes natural and cosmic forces, visible and invisible powers, and eternal ancestral pacts to animate and empower the magical object. The ritual involves burying the item in the earth for seven days and nights to absorb secrets, then exposing it to the sun's blessing, with the Sun as a witness to the perpetual alliance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Kunwana (Rezo para guerrear)
structure_content.summary: A 'warrior's prayer' used to concentrate and activate the spiritual energy of foundations for combat. The practitioner identifies with the warrior, rooster, fire, sun, earth, moon, and stars, drawing on their power to establish balance between the visible and invisible worlds and to combat negative forces. This prayer is deemed essential for initiating spiritual 'wars' or 'struggles'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu bia Nfumbe
structure_content.summary: A complex prayer/chant primarily directed at the Nfumbe (spirit of the dead), written in a mixed language (Kikongo, Spanish, and a creolized form). It addresses various aspects of the Nfumbe's power, domain, and ability to act, making it a highly versatile prayer for communication with ancestral spirits, performing magical works, and engaging in divination (Chamalongo). It is highlighted as an exceptionally important prayer within the Nzo de Palo tradition.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bisambulu zitisa na Nzambi (Rezo de respeto a Nzambi) Otra
structure_content.summary: Another variation of the prayer of respect to Nzambi, reinforcing God's singular nature, divine assistance in times of danger, and self-subsistence. It re-emphasizes the practitioner's testimony to Nzambi's absolute power and their own dependence.

key_concepts.definition: Prayers or orations, often secret and powerful, used in Palo Monte rituals.
Specific houses or lineages within the Palo Monte Mayombe tradition, from which these prayers originate.
A branch of the Afro-Cuban religion Palo Monte, characterized by its veneration of ancestors, nature spirits, and the use of sacred implements called Ngangas.
A sacred vessel or magical implement, often a cauldron, containing various natural elements and spiritual forces. It also refers to a practitioner or priest in Palo Monte.
The supreme God or creator deity in the Kongo cosmology, revered as omnipotent and the source of all life and power.
A spirit or deity associated with paths, crossroads, destiny, and communication in Palo Monte.

A powerful spirit, described in the text's translation as 'Diablo maléfico' (evil devil) for orientation, representing forces of the night, abysses, and the underworld, manipulated in certain Palo Monte ceremonies.
Ancestors; venerated spirits invoked for guidance, protection, and empowerment in Palo Monte rituals.
A sacred object, magical implement, foundation, or protective charm within Palo Monte, imbued with spiritual power and often synonymous with Nganga or fundamento.
A spiritual signature or sign drawn by the practitioner, used to invoke, mark, or activate energies and spirits during rituals.
A spirit associated with paths, roads, crossroads, and communication, often invoked to open spiritual pathways and enhance sensory perception in rituals.
A horn or vessel often used in Palo Monte for divination or to hold potent magical substances.
The spirit of the dead, specifically an ancestral or guiding spirit housed within a Nganga or other sacred object, central to many Palo Monte practices.
A practitioner or priest of Palo Monte Mayombe.
Core sacred objects or foundations of the Palo Monte religion, containing powerful spiritual forces and elements.
Protective charms or amulets, consecrated to provide spiritual defense.
A system of divination used in Palo Monte, typically involving four coconut shells or pieces.
Specific substances (likely water, rum, and an herbal infusion or other fluid) used for ritual purification of animals and other elements in Palo Monte.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a comprehensive system of operative magic rooted in Palo Monte Mayombe. It is centered on the use of specific prayers (bisambulu) in Kikongo and mixed languages, which act as invocations and commands to divine entities (Nzambi), ancestral spirits (Bakuluntu Bantete, Nfumbe), nature spirits (Mpungo Nzila), and the consecrated implements of the religion (Nganga, Prenda, Fundamentos). The system emphasizes establishing direct communication and pacts with these spiritual forces to effect change in the visible and invisible worlds. It covers a broad spectrum of magical operations, from daily spiritual upkeep and protection to aggressive spiritual warfare, consecration of ritual tools and substances, and various forms of divination and healing. The practitioner (Mayombero) uses these prayers, often in conjunction with specific ritual actions, Patibemba (spiritual signatures), and consecrated items, to channel and direct spiritual energy according to their will and the dictates of their spiritual lineage.
tools: Prenda (general term for sacred object, foundation, or magical implement)
Mpaka (horn or vessel for divination/holding magical substances)
Mansa, Malafo, Nzunga (purification substances, e.g., water, rum, herbal infusions)
Palos and Hierbas (specific woods and herbs used as ritual elements)
rituals: Daily prayers for divine blessing and guidance.
Invocation and respectful address to Nzambi, the Supreme Being.
Invoking and empowering the Nganga or Prenda (sacred vessel/implement).
Concentrating elemental and spiritual energy into ritual substances.
Requesting enhanced sensory perception from spiritual foundations (often with Nkuyo and Mpaka).
Executing offensive magic against enemies using forceful negative affirmations.
Sealing pacts with nature and consecrating new natural elements (palos and herbs).
Consecrating elements and ceremonies for manipulating 'forces of evil' (Kadia a Mpemba).
Invoking ancestral spirits to strengthen and protect the practitioner and ritual work.
Formal opening and closing of magical ceremonies.
Drawing cosmic forces from celestial bodies for ritual power.
Consecrating and purifying ceremonial water for ritual baths and sacralization.
Ritual purification of animals prior to sacrifice, involving direct communication and specific substances.
Naming and consecrating new Prendas, Fundamentos, or Resguardos, involving burial, exposure to the sun, and an eternal pact.
'Warrior' prayers for spiritual combat, balance, and defense against negative forces.
Multi-purpose prayers/chants for communication with the Nfumbe, performing works, and divination via Chamalongo.

relevant_quotes.text: En esta pequeña, pero muy grande libreta se recogen algunas de las poderosas oraciones secretas mas usadas del Nzo Vititi Kongo y mi Nzo Sarabanda.
Cada Bisambulu (Oración) esta escrita en una sola hoja, en la cara principal va la oración en Kikongo. En el reverso esta la oración en español y la manera para usarla.
Un sólo Dios poderoso, creador de todo nos proteja y esté contento porque lo tenemos cerca del corazón.

Este rezo es contundente y fulminante contra los enemigos del Mayombero, con sólo nombrarla puede destruir la negatividad proveniente de estos, y someterlos a su voluntad, es un ejemplo del poder benéfico de las prendas cuando se utilizan como defensoras.
(ha de comprenderse que los Kongo no tienen el concepto occidental de demonio o diablo) en la traducción usamos su nombre para orientarles.
Esta se usa para recolectar los elementos que componen la ceremonia así como los usados para montar fundamentos y resguardos. Es vital usarlo cuando se sella tratado con nuevos palos y hierbas.
Esta oración convierte al agua en una poderosa energía que aleja las influencias negativas y atrae las positivas.

Antes del sacrificio hay que hablarle, pedirle, rogarle, como si fuera la misma Nganga, porque el animal es el vínculo que comunica los dos mundos, por este motivo no pueden ser animales defectuosos ni mutilados...
Este rezo se usa nombrando cada uno de los elementos de la prenda que se esté montando, o también para un resguardo...
Esta oración escrita en un idioma mixto, sirve casi para todo, para hablar con el Nfumbe, para hacer obras, para tirar los Chamalongo, o sea, una oración muy importante en el Nzo de Palo.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant for both practitioners and scholars of Palo Monte. For practitioners, it provides a systematized and accessible (due to its bilingual format and explanations) collection of traditionally secret oral prayers, serving as a practical operational manual. It reinforces the core cosmological and theological tenets of Palo Monte Mayombe while offering explicit instructions for diverse magical applications, from daily spiritual maintenance to complex ritual workings and spiritual warfare. For scholars, it offers invaluable insight into the liturgical and operative aspects of a specific Palo Monte lineage, demonstrating the syncretic nature of the religion and the practical application of its philosophical framework.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is practitioners of Palo Monte Mayombe, particularly those within the Nzo Vititi Kongo and Nzo Sarabanda lineages, including Tatas (priests) and Yayas (priestesses). It is also highly valuable for students and researchers of Afro-Cuban religions, Western Esotericism, and Occultism who seek to understand the practical mechanics and spiritual philosophy of Palo Monte from an internal, operative perspective.
